results.title: How to use the telephone
results.creator_credit: Michael Law, H M Treasury and Public Relations Films
results.brief_description: A training film made for use in Government (British) departments pointing out common mistakes in using the telephone and showing how a proper understanding of the relationship between caller, switchboard and extension-user can save a great deal of valuable time and energy.

results.title: How to talk business to win
results.brief_description: Millard Bennett describes the self-education and techniques of a salesman concluding by reiterating the personal qualities and disclipine necessary to success in any field, including salesmanship.

results.title: How to supervise
results.creator_credit: David Pitt, Francis Gysin and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: Defines the responsibilities of the supervisor and reinforces the need for a civilised relationship between supervisor and trainee, by giving hints for supervisors on how they should attend to the training and safety of young entrants under their charge. Although made for the coal industry most of the ideas are generally applicable.

results.title: How to stay alive
results.creator_credit: Alan Landsburg, ABC News (US) and Alan Landsburg Productions
results.brief_description: Warning signals of heart disease show up in eight major areas of physical health. These danger signals are dramatised by documenting the lifestyles of five apparently healthy middle-aged men who are candidates for heart attacks. Each man’s doctor prescribes a change of living pattern that will greatly reduce the risk, and the extent to which the five accept their individual lifesaving prescriptions is shown. Narrated by Robert Young.

results.title: How to make a movie without a camera
results.creator_credit: Michael Warshaw, Mimi Warshaw and Rainy Day Productions
results.brief_description: Presents the results of efforts made to produce a film without a camera, using the following techniques to produce striking effects: vegetable dye colouring, felt-tipped pen, sprays and fingerprints all individually applied to clear leader; and scratching and perforating of opaque leader. The film is especially useful to young filmmakers.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Warshaw, Mimi Warshaw and Rainy Day Productions

results.title: How to keep from catching VD
results.brief_description: A health officer addresses a class of secondary school students about gonorrhea and syphilis. Using charts, he explains the immediate and long-range effects of each disease. Stress is placed on the possible prevention of the diseases through selective sexual behaviour, cleanliness and the use of mechanical devices.

results.title: How to have an accident in the home
results.creator_credit: Charles Nichols and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Mr Donald Duck, an average citizen, avoids numerous hazards on his way home from work, only to find that instead of being safe at home he is surrounded by all sorts of modern conveniences for accidents. Littered stairways, overloaded electric circuits, loose rugs, cleaning fluid and gas stoves combined with his own carelessness result in a series of vioolent explosions and other mishaps.

results.title: How to grow roses
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau and John Ott Pictures
results.brief_description: Outlines the rose’s origin, geographic distribution, and varying habits, form and character. Shows many of the 90 genera comprising the rose family. Includes practical hints on cultivation, general care and pruning.
